awd_titl_txt: Groups Representations and Applications: New Perspectives
awd_abstract_narration:
Group Theory is essentially the theory of symmetry for mathematical and physical systems, which underpins much of modern pure mathematics,  with major connections to physics, chemistry, and information science. Especially after the completion of the Classification of Finite Simple Groups (CFSG), important and deep connections to areas as varied as topology, algebraic geometry, Lie theory, homological algebra, and mathematical physics, have been discovered and exploited. Still, the area abounds with basic problems and long-standing conjectures. Recent breakthroughs hold out the prospect of finally solving some venerable open problems. In turn, recent results in group- and representation theory have led to substantial progress in a vast number of applications in Lie theory, number theory, algebraic geometry,combinatorics and semigroup theory.

All this wealth of new results and directions will be the main theme of the 2020 six-month program "Groups, Representations and Applications: New Perspectives", Jan. 6 - June 30, 2020, at the Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences (INI, Cambridge, UK), which features five one-week workshops. The goal of this program is to bring together the leading experts in group and representation theory, on the one hand, and from several key other parts of mathematics on the other, to tackle some of the main problems and to take the many connections between CFSG and other areas of mathematics to the next level. Detailed information is given at the program's website http://www.newton.ac.uk/event/gra. Funding provided by the grant will support US-based participants of the five one-week workshops within the program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the NSF conference grant DMS-1907670 was to support US-based graduate students, postdocs, and other mathematicians without, or with insufficient, funding support, to speak and participate in the workshops which are parts of the half-a-year research programme ``Groups, Representations, and Applications: New Perspectives'', Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences, Cambridge, UK, Jan. 6-June 30, 2020. Due to the pandemic, the programme was halted on March 18, 2020. The remaining activities of the programme, including the two workshops ``Counting conjectures and beyond'' and ``Simple groups, representations, and applications'', originally scheduled for May 2020 and June 2020, was decided by the Isaac Newton Institute to run May 3--July 29, 2022. Funds of the grant were used to support US-based participants of these two workshops ``Counting conjectures and beyond'' and ``Simple groups, representations, and applications''.

As approved by NSF in Oct. 2022, the remaining balance of the grant was used to support six speakers (Theo Douvropoulos, Tasho Kaletha, Hung Nguyen, Greta Panova, Amanda Schaeffer Fry, and Paul Sobaje)
and two participants (Serin Hong and Chenchen Zhao, both graduate students) of the special session ``Representation theory and applications'', The 2022 Pacific Rim Mathematical Association Congress, Vancouver,
Dec. 4-9, 2022, co-organized by the PI.
